required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Efficacy of Warming Device During Surgery
clinical_study.official_title: Efficacy of a New Intraoperative Resistive Warming Device

brief_summary.textblock: This study will test the hypothesis that an electric heating device, the Hot Dog warming system is as effective as the Bair Hugger forced air heating system.

detailed_description.textblock: Subjects undergoing major plastic surgery lasting approximately 5 hours will be randomized to either the Hot Dog resistive heating system or the Bair Hugger forced air heating system. Core temperature will be measured using a distal esophagus and mean skin temperature. Warming will continue until the subjects' core temperature reaches 37°C. Subsequent temperature will be adjusted as clinically necessary. Data will be recorded at 15 minute intervals. Core temperature will be first measured after intubation when the esophageal temperature probe is inserted. The primary outcome will be the rate of core rewarming over the range of 35°C to 37°C.

primary_outcome.measure: The Rate of Core Rewarming Over the Range From 35°C to 37°C.
primary_outcome.time_frame: Until the end of surgery, up to 5 hour
primary_outcome.description: The primary outcome was the rewarming rate during active heating over a core temperature range from 35°C to 37°C.

primary_outcome.measure: Intraoperative Time Weighted Average Core Temperature
primary_outcome.time_frame: Until the end of surgery, up to 5 hour
primary_outcome.description: Temperatures during surgery were recorded at 15-min intervals and summarize as time weighted average (TWA) for each patient. The unit of TWA-temperature is °C.

arm_group.description: Intraoperative warming with Bair Hugger forced air system
Intraoperative warming with Hot Dog resistive heating system

intervention.description: Intraoperative warming with Hotdog resistive heating system

study_pop.textblock: Patients undergoing major plastic surgery lasting approximately 5 hours.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Plastic surgery lasting approximately 5 hours
- Subjects over the age of 18 years
- Patient signed Informed Consent
Exclusion Criteria:
- Plastic surgery lasting less than 5 hours
- Individuals under the age of 18 years

group.title: Intra-operative Rewarming With Hot Dog
group.description: Intraoperative warming with Bair Hugger forced air system

group.title: Intra-operative Rewarming With Forced-air Heating
group.description: Intraoperative warming with forced-air heating system

measure.title: The Rate of Core Rewarming Over the Range From 35°C to 37°C.
measure.description: The primary outcome was the rewarming rate during active heating over a core temperature range from 35°C to 37°C.

analysis.groups_desc: A total of 46 patients (23 per group) were needed to have 90% power to demonstrate equivalence of the two warming methods on final intra-operative temperature at the 0.05 significance level using the 2 one-tailed tests equivalence testing technique and an equivalence region of 0.5 degrees C per hour, assuming a SD of 0.5 degrees C/hour for each group and zero true difference.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: Our primary outcome was the rate of core rewarming during the surgery. Groups were compared on mean rewarming rate in a linear mixed effects regression model with within-subject change of core temperature over time as random effect. Using those model results, equivalence on the mean rate of rewarming for the resistive and warm air systems was assessed with the 2 one-tailed tests equivalence testing approach and equivalence delta of 0.2 degrees C/hours.
analysis.p_value_desc: Two 1-tailed tests were conducted. P-value for lower delta was 0.91. Equivalence will be claimed if p-values for upper and lower delta are both lower than 0.05 ⁄ 2 = 0.025.
analysis.method_desc: Two 1-tailed tests were conducted to assess equivalence. See " Type of Statistical Test".

analysis.groups_desc: A total of 46 patients (23 per group) were needed to have 90% power to demonstrate equivalence of the two warming methods on final intra-operative temperature at the 0.05 significance level using the 2 one-tailed tests equivalence testing technique and an equivalence region of 0.5 degrees C per hour, assuming a SD of 0.5 degrees C/hour for each group and zero true difference.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: Our primary outcome was the rate of core rewarming during the surgery. Groups were compared on mean rewarming rate in a linear mixed effects regression model with within-subject change of core temperature over time as random effect. Using those model results, equivalence on the mean rate of rewarming for the resistive and warm air systems was assessed with the 2 one-tailed tests equivalence testing approach and equivalence delta of 0.2 degrees C/hours.
analysis.p_value_desc: Two 1-tailed tests were conducted. P-value for lower delta was 0.91. Equivalence will be claimed if p-values for upper and lower delta are both lower than 0.05 ⁄ 2 = 0.025.

outcome.title: Intraoperative Time Weighted Average Core Temperature
outcome.description: Temperatures during surgery were recorded at 15-min intervals and summarize as time weighted average (TWA) for each patient. The unit of TWA-temperature is °C.
outcome.time_frame: Until the end of surgery, up to 5 hour
outcome.population: Medical University of Vienna adults having major maxillary-facial reconstructive surgery expected to last about 5 h. Most had pectoral flap reconstructions after extensive cancer debridement. We did not study patients with Reynaud’s disease, thyroid dysfunction, insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, or who were of ASA physical status > 3.

group.title: Intraoperative Warming With Bair Hugger Forced Air System
group.description: Intraoperative temperature warming with Bair Hugger forced air system

group.title: Intraoperative Warming With Hot Dog Resistive Heating System
group.description: Intraoperative temperature warming with Hot Dog resistive heating system

measure.title: Intraoperative Time Weighted Average Core Temperature
measure.description: Temperatures during surgery were recorded at 15-min intervals and summarize as time weighted average (TWA) for each patient. The unit of TWA-temperature is °C.
measure.population: Medical University of Vienna adults having major maxillary-facial reconstructive surgery expected to last about 5 h. Most had pectoral flap reconstructions after extensive cancer debridement. We did not study patients with Reynaud’s disease, thyroid dysfunction, insulin-dependent diabetes mellitus, or who were of ASA physical status > 3.

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis is the Hot dog resistive heating system is inferior to the Bair Hugger forced air system. Mean difference (95% CI) of the intraoperative TWA temperature between the groups (resistive heating versus forced-air) will be adjusting for preoperative oral temperature and ASA physical status.
analysis.non_inferiority_desc: The non-inferiority margin is defined as 0.5 °C. Non-inferiority at the 0.025 significance level will be claimed if the lower limit of the 95% confidence interval is higher than the -0.5 °C.
analysis.p_value_desc: P-value was adjusted for preoperative oral temperature and ASA physical status.
analysis.estimate_desc: Non-inferiority will be established, at the 0.025 significance level, if the lower limit of a 95% confidence interval for the difference is above -0.5 °C.

reported_events.time_frame: From the beginning of the surgery until the end of surgery, up to 24 hour.

group.title: Bair Hugger Forced Air System
group.description: Patients were warmed with the Bair Hugger forced air system during surgery.

group.title: Hot Dog Resistive Heating System
group.description: Patients were warmed with the Hot Dog resistive heating system during surgery.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: There is NOT an agreement between Principal Investigators and the Sponsor (or its agents) that restricts the PI's rights to discuss or publish trial results after the trial is completed.

clinical_results.limitations_and_caveats: Unable to evaluate safety with small sample size. Smaller-than-expected sample size had enough power but confidence intervals for treatment effect wider than desired.
